Expectation1: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation1: The message is informational and the sender notes there is no immediate action required.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I stood in the long line at the polling station, my phone buzzing in my pocket. As a colleague, I always try to respond to emails and messages quickly, even if it’s just to acknowledge them. I glanced at my phone—an informational message from a teammate, nothing urgent, but I knew she appreciated prompt replies. At the same time, an election official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name fit the criteria, but the new line looked longer and slower. The instructions were clear, though, and I wanted to do my civic duty properly.

I felt a tug between my roles. Should I quickly reply to my colleague, risking being seen as distracted or disrespectful in the polling place? Or should I focus on following the official’s directions, even though it meant a longer wait and possibly delaying my response? The pressure of being a reliable coworker clashed with my desire to be a conscientious voter. I hesitated, caught between the expectations of my workplace and my responsibilities as a citizen, unsure which role to prioritize in that moment.
